title: Can we make assassins AFRAID of tanks again?
body:
I thought the original design that Assassins could not successfully attack and destroy tanks in League. However this simply is not the case anymore. Sure its harder, but with all the new damage items and damage creep in the game, an assassin can easily 1v1 and kill a tank. This is really disturbing to watch and really highlights the problems with the game at the moment.

Tanks are supposed to be countered by sustained damage like ADC's (less said about {{champion:67}}, swatter of squishies and tanks alike, the better) but it seems now that assassins are not even afraid of tanks anymore. {{champion:238}}, {{champion:105}} and {{champion:245}} can capitalise on a tank's lack of damage and just burst them down like they were a normal squishy. 

I want to go back to a season where League was actually about THINKING how to engage your opponent correctly, thinking about their strengths and weaknesses and not the reaction "fighting-game" style "beat-em-up", its become recently. League should not be a reaction test, it should be about balanced, strategic picks and objective control.

I'd argue that Naut has far better continuous contribution to a fight, although Malph has better initiation. In terms of control, Malphite is actually very mediocre, but he makes up for it with godlike initiation and insane durability against physical damage. Nautilus by comparison has endless waves of CC that never really stops until he's killed. You can afford to be near a Malphite when his ult is down. Naut, not so much.

A tank isn't defined by its CC, hat is a secondary facility. A tank has ability to tank damage.

And in that department, They tank more or less the same against AP (assuming same items/levels), but Malphite tanks way better against AD, so Malphite is a better tank.

So, by your definiton, a full attack speed Nautilus is still a better tank than a normal build Malphite? Just because he has better CC?

A tank is defined by how well they can exert control from a frontline position. They are not defined by their ability to take damage, otherwise any champ built tanky could be considered a tank. In order to exert that control, you need to be able to both CC enemies that enter into your zone of control and you need to be able to take punishment. Malphite is very good at taking punishment but he's not very good at controlling enemies; once his ult is down, his only CC is his Q slow which is more of a chasing tool given how it's designed. Nautilus by comparion has spammable a spammable AOE slow, snares on his autoattacks, and his hook in addition to his ult, with his W helping him to stay alive. With that in mind, Nautilus is a better tank; the control he exerts in the frontline while also being hard to kill is unparallelled by pretty much any champion in the game. While Malphite is indeed very tanky, he's more of an initiator that turns into an extremely tanky bruiser after ulting rather than a true tank.
Woah, woah, woah. Buddy, what makes Sion a shit tank to you?
Massively telegraphed CC, no defense steroid beside a health stacking mechanic that barely compensates for his shit base stats?

It's massively telegraphed, but ignoring damage, it serves two purposes. It's meant to disrupt enemies or to punish them for not moving. He has high durations on his stuns and slows when it comes to when they're fully charged, because its punishing them for not getting the F**k out of the way. 

Even if they miss, they serve the purpose of them either wasting CC on you, or putting themselves in a less optimal position than before. He's great for peeling for Carries, since he can set a zone of "You no go here", and can provide immediate disruption by point blanking his ult. His slow also shreds armor, so he helps kill tanks or complement burst on a carry. 

This may be a rant, but Sion is soooooo much not a shit tank. Sure, he may not have the defensive traits of Malphite, Maokai, or  Alistair, but he has the most disruption of a fight, next to Zac of course, that you could want. 

(also if you build Titanic Hydra and Righteous Glory, say goodbye to carries if you die)

Again, no one is questioning Sion's strength as a JUGGERNAUT, which is exactly what you're describing. He's a great juggernaut. However, as a TANK he is still far inferior to other choices. If an assassin is coming for my ADC, Sion has a snowball's chance in hell of stopping them in time because his CC is very avoidable. Alistair, Leona, Singed, and Maokai all have point and click hard CCs that CAN'T be dodged, Malphite can just ult at the ADC's feet, Tahm Kench can just EAT the ADC and giggle while he runs away... Sion's only choices for hard CC in this scenario are to ult at point blank range, which will barely knock them up, or charge Q and hope the assassin fails to 100-0 the ADC in the time it takes to charge fully. Or, y'know, not step a few steps to the side.

Alistair, Tahm and Leona are support tanks. Their entire job as a tank is to either lock down enemies for the carry, or to babysit the carry. If we compare real tanks, {{champion:14}} {{champion:54}} {{champion:111}} {{champion:154}} {{champion:57}} {{champion:20}}, you notice a trend of being able to heavily disrupt a team through starting fights and heavy aoe CC/aoe "ya don't want to be here" zones. 

Malphite is great for diving backlines and punishing people who clump, and if he wants to babysit a carry he can. Nautilius isolates and drags back people to start fights, following up with his Ult to knockup anyone who tries to protect the target. Once again, if he wants to babysit a carry, he can. Maokai lowers damage for his entire team, while also locking down individual targets, making him much more support-ish in a way, but he has the choice to use it offensively or defensively. 

This brings us back to Sion. He is great to start fights, and is great at locking down targets, but if he wants to babysit a carry, he can. He can stay right near them, ready to point blank his ult at the ready, because even a small knock up, gives enough time for others to follow up.

AND YOU EVEN PROVED MY POINT. 

> Or, y'know not to step a few steps to the side.

If they are moving out of his Q, it means that they aren't killing people. It means that Sion is ruining their plan, because they HAVE to take a "Few" steps to the side to avoid getting CC'd. Using Zed as an example, he'd either have to walk out of it, or use a shadow to switch out of. If he used his shadow, than he loses out on a lot of damage for assassinating a Carry, because his Shadow is out by you.

You define tanks as "They cc people, so if they can't cc fast, they're bad" and that is not the point. Sion is not about landing CC, he is about disrupting a teamfight just as REAL tanks do, not support tanks who focus on a single person or baby sitting. He can, if he wants, babysit a carry, but that is not where his true strength shines. Naut, Malph, Zac and Sion are about disruption, forcing people to change plans, and just because they don't fit a Tank Support's role, does not mean they're "Shit"

The thing is those 3 champs listed don't have any issues with tanks because they are bad designs for assassins(namely {{champion:105}} {{champion:245}}  having too much mobility); A more traditional assassin like Kat or Talon would be worried for tanks ccing them out for the team to burst them.

Assassins have always been able to 1v1 tanks if given the time to do so. The questions is: Why are you 1v1ing assassins as a tank? Tanks are a threat to assassins in teamfights because of their CC and anti-burst potential, not because they can 1v1 the assassin. If you want to beat the assassin 1v1, then bruisers {{champion:102}} {{champion:48}} {{champion:39}} {{champion:24}} {{champion:36}} {{champion:122}} {{champion:86}} {{champion:78}} {{champion:82}} are what you're looking for and always have been. Don't expect to 1v1 Fizz or Zed with Maokai. But Irelia will destroy either of those kids.

I promise to you right now that I am indeed still afraid of tanks, and I have been for 3 years now.

{{item:3147}} 
Remove this assassin item that kills tanks

In a Void, assassins beat tanks. But that is in a void, where tanks are isolated from their greatest strength: Their Team. Tanks are the most team players you'll find, next to supports, whose job is to throw themselves in to take the damage, so others don't. This is complemented by their CC, as it allows allies to safely attack enemies. 

Just because you are a tank, doesn't mean you instawin/can't be killed by assassins. Tanks will always rely on their team more than any class (Non-tank supports are usually backline, protected by tanks) because that is their base design. And in no way in hell, will a tank be bursted unless the assassin is super fed.
